description: Unclear, perhaps from a southern African language; from late 19thC, revived during World War I.

entries.meaning: (Britain, military slang) Jam (“fruit conserve made from fruit boiled with sugar”).
examples: ‘Could you pinch a tin of pozzy out of stores?’

description: From position +‎ -y (“diminutive suffix”), with spelling shift; variant of possie.

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, military slang, Digger slang) A firing position.
examples: […] and Jerry O′Dwyer had shot two crows from the new sniper′s pozzy down at the creek-—and so on.

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, colloquial) A position or place, especially one that is advantageous.
examples: So I says to him, no, I can′t go back to the pozzy I′m sharing with Snowy Fisher and the late Pap.
